intro: Acalypha trukensis, commonly known as the Truk Island glorybower, is a flowering plant native to the Micronesian island of Truk. It belongs to the Euphorbiaceae family and is characterized by its striking, showy bracts that resemble flowers. The plant typically grows as a shrub or small tree, reaching heights of up to 3 meters. Its leaves are usually ovate or elliptic, with a smooth or slightly hairy surface. Acalypha trukensis is adapted to coastal environments and is often found in sandy or rocky soils.
distribution_native_art_desc: Acalypha trukensis is primarily native to the Truk Islands, which are part of the Caroline Islands in the Pacific Ocean. This species is found in the tropical regions of Micronesia, specifically on the island of Truk. It thrives in coastal and lowland areas with high humidity and warm temperatures. The plant is adapted to the unique environmental conditions of its native habitat. Due to its restricted distribution, it is considered a rare and endemic species in the region.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Acalypha trukensis was mainly introduced to tropical and subtropical regions, particularly in the Pacific Islands. It thrives in warm, humid climates with well-drained soil. This plant is commonly found in coastal areas and disturbed sites due to its adaptability.
